    <figure class="col-lg-3 col-md-3 col-sm-3 col-xs-12  article-image pull-left clear-left">
        <img src="http://images.agoramedia.com/everydayhealth/cms/chelation-therapy-article.jpg?width=200" id="eh-share-img" />

                    <div class="article-content">
                            <div class="article-body" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
        <p><strong>WEDNESDAY, March 27, 2013 —</strong> Heart disease patients might need to rethink their elation over chelation therapy, according to Steven E. Nissen, MD, head of cardiovascular medicine at the Cleveland Clinic, in an editorial in the current issue of JAMA.</p>
<p>Nissen was responding to the JAMA publication of the results of a study <a href="http://www.everydayhealth.com/heart-health/1105/controversial-alternative-heart-treatment-shows-hint-of-benefit.aspx">originally presented last fall</a> at the American Heart Association annual meeting.</p>
<p>"Unfortunately, the efforts of these investigators fell short of the minimum level of quality necessary to adequately answer the question they sought to investigate," Dr. Nissen wrote.</p>
<p>In the study, which was part of the Trial to Assess Chelation Therapy (TACT), an ongoing investigation possible <a href="http://www.everydayhealth.com/alternative-health/treatment-regimens/heart-health-and-alternative-therapies.aspx">merits of chelation therapy </a>by the U.S. National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, the controversial alternative therapy only modestly reduced the risk of further cardiovascular problems in patients with a history of heart attack.</p>
<p>In chelation treatments, patients receive a series of infusions of an amino acid called EDTA (ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid), which binds to heavy metals and minerals and pushes them out through urine. The idea behind chelation therapy for heart disease is that EDTA may also remove calcium deposits that can block arteries.</p>
<p>
    <div class="col-lg-4 col-md-4 col-sm-4 col-xs-12 pull-right clear-right ad-content">
    <div class="ad-container ad-standard">
        <div id="adDiv7" class="ad-placeholder"
            title="Advertisement" 
             data-adsize="[[300,250],[300,600]]"
            data-pos="bottomsticky"
            data-tile="7">
        </div>
        
    </div>
</div>
</p>
<p>Researchers in the TACT trial looked at 1,708 patients over the age of 50 with a recent history of heart attack, 311 of whom dropped out before the trial was completed. Patients either received 40 infusions of a chelation solution, an oral vitamin-mineral regimen and a placebo, or just a placebo.</p>
<p>
    <div class="col-lg-4 col-md-4 col-sm-4 col-xs-12 pull-right clear-right ad-content">
    <div class="ad-container ad-standard">
        <div id="adDiv9" class="ad-placeholder"
            title="Advertisement" 
             data-adsize="[[300,250]]"
            data-pos="extrasticky"
            data-tile="9">
        </div>
        
    </div>
</div>
</p>
<p>The researchers found that 87 patients on chelation therapy died compared to 93 on a placebo. The numbers for heart attacks were similar – 6 percent for patients on chelation therapy and 8 percent for patients on the placebo.</p>
<p>"These results provide evidence to guide further research but are not sufficient to support the routine use of chelation therapy for treatment of patients who have had a [heart attack]," concluded the study's authors.</p>
<p>But in his editorial, Nissen criticized the researchers for bias, not equally distributing the study groups after 311 patients dropped out, and setting up arbitrary endpoints.</p>
<p>"Given the numerous concerns with this expensive, federally funded clinical trial, including missing data, potential investigator or patient unmasking, use of subjective end points, and intentional unblinding of the sponsor, the results cannot be accepted as reliable and do not demonstrate a benefit of chelation therapy," Nissen explained. "The findings of TACT should not be used as a justification for <a href="http://www.everydayhealth.com/heart-health/1105/dismay-greets-positive-chelation-study.aspx">increased use of this controversial therapy</a>."</p>
<p>Despite Nissen and other doctors' misgivings about the study, it was accepted by JAMA, a peer-reviewed medical journal, and evidently met the journal's standards for accuracy and stringency of study design.</p>
<h2><strong>Ongoing Skepticism About Chelation Therapy</strong></h2>
<p>Critics have been skeptical of alleged benefits of chelation therapy since its creation in the 1950s. Chelation therapy has been proven to help patients with lead poisoning, but results have been mixed in other research.  While chelation therapists claim the procedure has benefits for those with heart disease and conditions such as autism, critics like Nissen continue criticize it as unproven, risky, and dangerous.</p>
<p>In 2006, the FDA attributed the deaths of two children to chelation therapy for autism.</p>
<p>Chelation therapy is performed on over 100,000 Americans with heart disease each year. Each treatment costs about $5,000.</p>
    </div>
